notes: 1st ed.

6.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
6.title: "Bert 'n' Bob Contemplate the Comics Scene"
6.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: About soul-baring, teeth-gnashing, Mark Trail, Red Ryder, S&M, punch lines, and Hagar the Horrible.
Printed also in The Comics Journal, no. 200 (Dec. 1997), p. 113.

7.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
7.title: "Bert 'n' Bob Continue Ruminating"
7.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: Bob wanted to be a comic book artist; are comic books dead as a medium?; Bert's wife laughs at Dr. Katz.
Also printed in The Comics Journal, no. 200 (Dec. 1997), p. 113.

8.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
8.title: "Bowser's Boundaries"
8.author: Bill Griffith
notes: Summary: Zippy goes to Doggie for guidance and consolation, but Doggie's professionalism means he doesn't want Zippy climbing up on his head.

9.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
9.title: "A Boy and His God"
9.author: Bill Griffith
notes: Summary: Doggie goes to the country to get away from urban angst, striving, and lust, and Zippy finds him.

10.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
10.title: "Brand Loyalty"
10.author: Bill Griffith
notes: Summary: Zippy has been hanging out with another advertising icon, Mister Softee, and Doggie smells the vanilla.

11.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
11.title: "Cartoonish Dialogue"
11.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: Meltdown comments on The New Yorker magazine.
Key words: Changes, cartoons, articles, O.J. Simpson, fashions, National Star, Cosmo.

12.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
12.title: "Children of the Night"
12.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: Bert and Bob talk in an empty diner about television: Sipowicz, teletubbies, and that dog on Frasier.

33.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
33.title: "Hearing Voices"
33.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: Zippy's voice described in comparison with the voices of William Bendix, Fred Gwynne, Raymond Burr, John Goodman, and Julia Child.
Key words: Rotundity, wet feedback, dazed innocence, resonant earnestness, precise authority, calm reassurance, puzzling girlishness.

34.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-
34.title: "In France, Jeffy is Worshipped like a God!"
34.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: At a rest stop on the bus line at Kingman, Arizona, Zippy falls into a conversation about the Family Circus.

36.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-

36.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: The Saturn-owners cult: "at least we know what planet they're headed for!"

40.heading: Griffith, Bill, 1944-

notes: Summary: A company makes fake ice (Zippy's favorite rapper) for advertising, onto which you airbrush your subliminal message; Zippy gets Ovaltine because he saw the Brady Bunch in a milk bubble.

129.heading: Griffith, D. W. (David Wark), 1875-1948.
129.title: "The Image in Motion"
129.author: by Tappan W
129.appears_in: King. p. 11-18 in Crimmer's: The Harvard Journal of Pictorial Fiction (Winter 1975)
notes: SUMMARY: "The author traces the 20th century's fascination with movement, starting from Muybridge's photographic dissection of a man running and evolving through various artistic schools and media, cubism in painting, Hogarth in narrative art, Griffith in film. Comics especially are examined for their evolution from the key figure of Winsor McCay."

130.heading: Griffith, D. W. (David Wark), 1875-1948.
130.title: "Mr. Griffith, Meet Winsor McCay"
130.author: John L
130.appears_in: Fell. p. 89-121 (chapter 5) in Film and the Narrative Tradition (Norman : University of Oklahoma Press, 1974)
notes: Samples printed as figures are from Winsor McCay's "Little Nemo in Slumberland" and "Dream of the Rarebit Fiend," Chips and Comic Cuts (British magazines), J.R. Bray's "Mr. O.U. Absent Mind," "Peck's Bad Boy," C.W. Kahles' "Hairbreadth Harry," Frederic Opper, Louis Forton's "La Bande des Pieds-Nickelés," Rodolphe Töpffer, Gene Colan's "Dr. Strange," and Marvel's "Captain Marvel."

179.heading: Griffy.

notes: Summary: Griffy and Zippy describe the neighbors on their block.

180.heading: Griffy.
180.title: "Why Do th' Tips of Ballpoint Pens Develop Those Annoying, Inky Fuzzballs?"
180.author: Griffy.
notes: Summary: Zippy's having trouble setting the snooze alarm, and speaks of being born, getting dressed, having breakfast, going to school, getting married, working, shopping, reproducing and dying. Griffy asks him what part he doesn't get.

181.heading: Griffy.
181.title: "Zippy, and his Head, Make a Point"
181.author: Griffy
181.appears_in: reprinted on p. 34 of Editor & Publisher, v. 126, no. 31 (July 31, 1993).
notes: Summary: Zippy sees a crowd of people wearing cones on their heads, and thinks it's a tribute to him; Griffy says they're fans of the Coneheads movie and asks if he's going to file a lawsuit, but Zippy forgives them.
Title from caption applied by E&P.
